Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2011 03:11PM Panmars wrote: Not everything shows up on ultrasound or mammogram. I would get another opinion as soon as you can, or insist with your current doc that you want to know what it is. Don't let them tell you it's nothing when they have only run those 2 tests. You have palpable lumps. They are something, and you deserve to know what they are.
Posts.Title: Feeling like my doctor won't listen to me medfordmom Cowgirl13

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 11:04AM Panmars wrote: First of all, take a deep breath......then let it out. I know the waiting is torture, and it's a double whammy for you having postpartum. But don't get ahead of yourself. I know that's hard to do, too, but up to 80 percent of breast lumps are benign, especially in women under 50 years of age. So try to relax, stay positive, and if it does turn out to be a malignancy, you have found the absolute best website for support and information, and we are here for you. Wishing you the best of luck, and sending hugs your way.  Sandi
Posts.Title: Terrified I have Pregnancy Associated Breast Cancer inyoureyes inyoureyes

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 09:47AM Panmars wrote: Lme002, don't sweat it. The wire localization is easy peasy. They numb you up good, put in a thin, flexible wire guided by ultrasound, you won't even know it's in there. They did that for me the day of my surgery. I didn't feel a thing. It's the best way for the surgeon to pinpoint the center of the lesion. You'll do fine!  {{{hugs}}}
Posts.Title: Should I Be Worried Lme002 Lme002

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 03:43PM Panmars wrote: I saw it too. Can barely see through the tears to type. You said it granny....damn this friggin disease!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 08:09AM Panmars wrote: notme583, I did rads, and had no problems at all. No fatigue, just redness and some itching. I didn't peel or anything. It was the easiest part of my treatment. I've had more problems with the tamoxifen, frankly, but even that is not too bad. Everyone reacts differently to treatment...some sail through with no problems, others have more adverse side effects. If I were you, I would talk to the radiation oncologist, see what they have to say, and then decide. Hugs,  Sandi
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 05:50PM Panmars wrote: hawk, I used aloe vera gel ( the clear kind, without the blue or green dye ) and Eucerin Aquaphor Healing ointment. Messy stuff, but they were the only 2 things I was allowed to use. I used them both 3 to 4 times per day, and it made all the difference. I used them for a month following completion of rads, too.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 08:03AM Panmars wrote: SueJR, a surgical biopsy usually means they will take several samples of the lump through a tiny incision, done under a local anesthetic and guided by ultrasound. They took 4 samples on me, and it gave a very clear impression of my tumor. The procedure wasn't as scary as I thought it would be. Hang in there. Sending you hugs! Sandi

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 08:19AM Panmars wrote: Stacy_harp, you should try and find a breast surgeon, that would be the best. Your primary doc should be able to find one for you. Or if you have a breast center near where you live, you can usually just call them yourself and make an appointment. My next door neighbor was having some cystic problems in her right breast, so I gave her the number to my breast surgeon and she just called and got an appointment a week later. And when it comes to this sort of thing, you can never blow it out of proportion. Do what you need to do. Sending hugs your way! Sandi

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 05:45PM Panmars wrote: lynnieC, you should tell the docs about the lymph node and ultrasound history, and I would certainly ask about an MRI. And remember, 80 percent of lumps are benign. Hugs to all, Sandi

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2011 09:01AM Panmars wrote: Congrats, Tina ( I'm a day late too, sorry! ) A milestone for sure. I celebrated my one year last month. Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 05:26PM Panmars wrote: lynnieC, I did not have a palpable lump, and a routine mammo found invasive ductal carcinoma. Even after we knew where it was, none of my doctors, nor myself, could feel it. I have dense breast tissue, so that may have been part of why no one could feel it, plus it depends on it's location within the tissue. Mine was fairly deep. So it's possible to have BC with no palpable lump, though I couldn't tell you what percentage it is.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2011 03:30PM Panmars wrote: I'm still early, seeing my MO every three months, but they do lab tests every time, to make sure the tamoxifen isn't destroying my liver or kidneys, and to make sure the cancer markers are where they should be. My MO does a very thorough exam too, and is a very caring, sweet woman. Yeah, I wait a long time too sometimes, but I'll keep seeing her until that 5 year mark when I stop the tamoxifen. Just peace of mind, I guess.
